posts.cooked: Hi there! Over the summer, I want to try to create our own limelight. Is there a place I can find a guide to help me get started, or could anyone lay out some steps to follow? Thank you.

posts.name: Zach Orr
posts.cooked:
Checkout something like Glowworm - an open source Limelight alternative. The PCB and case are all available on GitHub.

Edit: Assuming you‚Äôre talking about the hardware of a Limelight here. Software is a different story.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
Our team used to make our own ‚Äúlimelight‚Äù using a Microsoft lifecam and a led ring that was attached around it.

We then ran the camera and vision pipeline from a Nvidia Jetson or Raspberry Pi. Here is the repo for our vision pipeline. https://github.com/FRC-Team-4143/vision-stronghold

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked: Depending on your goals, this may be a good place to start: https://www.playingwithfusion.com/productview.php?pdid=133

link_counts.title: Playing With Fusion - SnakeEyes (Green) Visible Raspberry Pi HAT for FRC Robotic Vision

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Zach_O:

Checkout something like Glowworm

Yeah, 3468 is lucky enough to have a Gloworm from the beta run, and I believe it will become a hit once we can get over the silicon shortage and get a couple seasons of ‚Äúhardening‚Äù under its belt.

Lexeo:

Playing With Fusion - SnakeEyes (Green) Visible Raspberry Pi HAT for FRC Robotic Vision

I haven‚Äôt used the SnakeEyes Hat before, but it too looks like a really good product if you already have a Raspberry Pi to use it in conjunction with.

For Software, PhotonVision is most similar to the Limelight software. I recommend a Raspberry Pi 3 if possible for PhotonVision as it is able to take advantage of libraries that can use the Pi‚Äôs GPU to accelerate the image processing that it can‚Äôt do (at least not yet) with a Raspberry Pi 4.

So yeah, if you have a Raspberry Pi 3 (or can find one for not over $100 with the current scalping), the closest to parody with the Limelight would be to get the SnakeEyes from Playing with Fusion and running PhotonVision on it.

posts.name: Inverse Laplace
posts.cooked: photonvision is good. nice GUI, easy incorporation in code with photonlib.

posts.name: Adan Silva
posts.cooked:
One of our mentors wrote a guide on how we built our camera for the 2020 season: https://www.instructables.com/Raspberry-PI-Vision-Processor-SpartaCam/ . It uses ChameleonVision in it, but you could easily just flash it with PhotonVision. We‚Äôve have been innovating it over the past couple of years, running with the second version for 2022 (the picture shows one on our swerve drive offseason chassis) and with a plan of a third one for 2023! image 3024√ó4032 1.51 MB

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
We used a SnakeEyes hat on a Raspberry Pi 4. It worked brilliantly, and was much cheaper than a Limelight. Also, please use a v1 Pi cam, you‚Äôll be glad you did. The v2 cam has terrible FOV.

Contribute to PlayingWithFusion/SnakeEyesDocs development by creating an account on GitHub.
